title: (x) Handwritten text. Need similar close font - Artistamp, Snell Roundhand, similar to Rubber Stamp {Lex, Jan via Lars, Mike Y}
tags: Need similar font for handwritten text
content:
There are 3 lines of text in the image.  
1) NUMBER 1  
2)Lompoc High School  
3)2010

I know these 3 are handwritten but can i get somewhere close font for these text?

here is the link for the image.

[http://wtf2.myfonts.com/uploads/images/a0/a0f34bb582677c65d721a91eb78086...](http://web.archive.org/web/20131028022444/http:/wtf2.myfonts.com/uploads/images/a0/a0f34bb582677c65d721a91eb780862e.41453.jpeg "http://wtf2.myfonts.com/uploads/images/a0/a0f34bb582677c65d721a91eb780862e.41453.jpeg")
author: artslons

comments.content:
These don't look handwritten to me - they look scanned with an edge detect filter added. Do you have the original scan? Cyan on White is not very readable. I tried to darken it but all I got was this:

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20131028022444im_/http:/typophile.com/files/a0f34bb582677c65d721a91eb780862e_5047.41453.jpeg)

"NUMBER 1" is Artistamp from [Harold's Fonts](http://web.archive.org/web/20131028022444/http:/www.haroldsfonts.com/rubberstamp.html)

2011 looks like it's a grunge version of an existing font (the '1's have the same distress).

- Lex

I think you might use "Rubber Stamp" for 2011. I think a Photoshop (or similar) noise technique was used, and perhaps the 0 was inverted, but the basic letterforms are very close.

The Script in the middle is completely unreadable to me, and you might as well pick any formal connected script as worry about trying to match something so unrecognizable, in my opinion.

- Mike Yanega

The script (or as much of it as I can see) looks like Ballantines to me.

- Lex

[Snell Roundhand](http://web.archive.org/web/20131028022444/http:/www.myfonts.com/WhatTheFont/forum/viewthread.php?threadid=258564) for the script as Lars reveiled.

Note: Artslons always posts in (min.) two forums with the same request at the same time.

So, it would be fine if you could post the answers here (or there), too, Artslons.
Artslons: It would be nice to post the answers you get from other forums here, too. Or there, also.
